caption: One of the shorter bridges across the Seine in the main tourist area close to Notre Dame.
This is a single arch iron bridge, spanning  the seine, built in the mid 1800‚Äôs , by the engineer Alphonse Oudrey and Nicolas Cadiat. The bridge is a popular hang out for buskers,

Connecting two of the trendiest areas in Paris this 200yo wrought iron bridge attracts a large number of music buskers and street performers. Though architecturally unexciting; the foot traffic is accommodated by an unusually large footpath. It also has notable historical significance with its inception during the second French Revolution of 1830, as well as it's military use during the Liberation of Paris in 1944.

Enjoy the view on river Seine. From here @notredame is very close to see. These days it's guarded with police but still can be seen very closely. One has to experience the old world charm of Paris when you are there. There's so much to see on foot, the old bridges, the beautiful old buildings with architecture that's so awesome. And here I'm referring to old Paris. You can drink in the charm of the beauty you'll find. And if you want a bite, Google some of the finest eateries that cater to the taste of everyone. Including an Indian hotel we found tucked away in one of the by Lanes near the Notre Dame
The Pont d'Arcole Bridge in Paris was built in the 19th century from the Ile de la Cite across the Seine River to the Right Bank and City Hall. The construction was innovative.

Beautiful view of the river Seine. After visiting Hotel de Ville (There's an office of tourism here. The BHV Marais across the street is a great place for shopping), cross the bridge Pont d'Arcole and walk down the street (rue d'Arcole). In a few minutes you'll see  the magnificent Notre Dame de Paris. Really beautiful area.

Ok, so this is your average Parisian bridge. But I don't know how, I was never (I really mean it, never) disappointed by the street musicians over there. From someone literally stealing Freddy's voice to the dog man (actually a dog singing with a man on his side, mind you) I am always fascinated and transposed to another dimension. Obviously, I'm exaggerating a bit, but you get the point.

The Pont d'Arcole is a bridge in Paris over the River Seine. It is served by the Metro station H√¥tel de Ville. The need for a bridge communicating between place de had been felt for years. he first two years of its life, its present name - according to the most generally accepted hypothesis - comes from the Battle of the Bridge of Arcole, in which Napoleon personally led a charge waving the tricolour and defeated the Austrians in 1796. The other hypothesis is that a young republican killed in the "Three Glorious Days" of the July Revolution - cut down as he planted the tricolour - cried "Remember that I am called Arcole" just before his death, presumably as he was imitating Bonaparte's action.
